case_vignette:
A 13-year-old Hispanic boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and is aggravated on walking. He fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not see a doctor about it and does not recall any immediate and persistent pain after the event. He has hypothyroidism. His only medication is levothyroxine. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears uncomfortable. He is at the 50th percentile for height and at the 95th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The patient has a left-sided, antalgic gait. The left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation and internal rotation is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 9,100/mm3
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Serum
TSH 3.6 μU/mL
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having left groin pain for a month that gets worse when I walk and it also spreads down to my left knee.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your left groin or knee?
Yes, I fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago.
Have you had any swelling or bruising in your left groin or knee after the fall?
I don't remember having any immediate and persistent pain after the fall.
Have you had any difficulty walking or standing for extended periods of time?
It hurts to walk, and I'm walking with a limp favoring my left side.
Have you had any difficulty climbing stairs or going uphill?
I am uncomfortable and have pain, which gets worse on walking.
Have you had any difficulty with your left knee locking or popping?
I haven't mentioned anything about my knee locking or popping.
Have you had any difficulty with your left knee giving out or buckling?
I haven't mentioned anything about my knee giving out or buckling.
Have you had any difficulty with your left knee feeling weak or unstable?
I haven't said anything about my knee feeling weak or unstable.
Have you had any difficulty with your left knee feeling numb or tingling?
No, I haven't mentioned any numbness or tingling in my knee.
Have you had any difficulty with your left knee feeling hot or red?
No, I haven't mentioned my knee feeling hot or turning red.
Have you had any difficulty with your left knee feeling swollen or tender?
I haven't said anything about my knee being swollen, but my left hip is tender.
Have you had any difficulty with your left hip feeling numb or tingling?
No, I haven't mentioned any numbness or tingling in my left hip.
Have you had any difficulty with your left hip feeling hot or red?
No, I haven't mentioned my hip feeling hot or looking red.
Have you had any difficulty with your left hip feeling swollen or tender?
My left hip is tender when touched.
Have you had any difficulty with your left hip feeling stiff or limited in range of motion?

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient has been experiencing left groin pain for a month, which worsens with walking and spreads down to the left knee. The pain started after a fall during soccer practice 5 weeks ago, with no immediate or persistent pain afterward. The patient is walking with a limp, favoring the left side, and has discomfort and increased pain while walking. There is no mention of knee locking, popping, giving out, buckling, weakness, instability, numbness, tingling, heat, redness, or swelling in the knee, but the left hip is tender when touched. There is also no mention of numbness, tingling, heat, redness, or swelling in the left hip.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: Developmental dysplasia of the left hip.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is a hip fracture.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: **Final Diagnosis:** Developmental dysplasia of the left hip.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having left groin pain for about a month, and it gets worse when I walk and also spreads down to my left knee.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your left groin area?
Yes, I fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago.
Have you had any other symptoms such as fever, chills, or difficulty walking?
I haven't had a fever or chills, but walking is uncomfortable, and I'm limping a bit on my left side.
Have you had any previous surgeries or medical conditions related to your left groin or knee?
No, I haven't had any surgeries, but I do have hypothyroidism.
Have you been taking any medications for your hypothyroidism?
Yes, I'm taking levothyroxine for my hypothyroidism.
Have you noticed any changes in your thyroid function or any other symptoms related to your hypothyroidism?
No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms related to my hypothyroidism.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or exercise routine?
No, I haven't made any recent changes to my diet or exercise routine.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to any new environments?
No, I haven't traveled recently or been exposed to new environments.
Have you had any family members with similar symptoms or medical conditions?
No, my family members haven't had similar symptoms or conditions.
Based on the information provided, the final diagnosis is **Osteochondritis Dissecans (OCD) of the left knee**.
